Award.AwardTitle: Connectivity and ION Conductions in Fuel Cell Membranes Probed by Tunneling Atomic Force Microscopy
Award.AbstractNarration:
With support from the Chemical Measurement and Imaging Program in the Division of Chemistry, and co-funding from the Polymers Program in the Division of Materials Research, Professor Steven Buratto and his group at University of California-Santa Barbara are utilizing conductive atomic force microscopy (c-AFM) to image ion conductance and pore connectivity in proton exchange membranes (PEM) used in PEM fuel cells on a nanometer length scale and at the level of a single pore channel. PEM fuel cells, which convert chemical energy into electricity using an electrochemical cell, can be used as efficient power sources, offering high power density and low environmental impact. Critical to fuel cell performance is the polymer electrolyte membrane, which is an efficient proton conductor but an electric insulator. A detailed understanding of proton conduction, in terms of the size and distribution of the chemical domains responsible for transport, is crucial to both a complete understanding of fuel cell performance and a systematic approach to improving the performance. To this end, c-AFM will be used to correlate phase and current images taken on an operating half fuel cell and determine the fraction of electrochemically-active aqueous surface domains. The PI and his group will also image the nanoscale domain morphology and connectivity as a function of (1) the environmental conditions that more accurately reflect those of an operating fuel cell such as high temperature and low relative humidity, (2) the membrane type and composition, and (3) the proximity of the catalyst particles to the ion channels. The results of these experiments will be used to gain a fundamental understanding of ion conductance in PEM fuel cells and provide inspiration and insight into the development of the next-generation membranes materials.

The possibility of producing power with efficiency greater than internal combustion engines, and with environmentally benign byproducts, makes fuel cells an important player in the field of alternative energy and sustainability, especially if the reactants are derived from renewable resources. Students working on this project will be exposed to this alternative source of power, help optimize industrial processes that produce polyelectrolyte membranes, and provide important insight into the discovery of new membrane materials. In addition, students will be trained in state-of-the-art scanned probe microscopy and nano-characterization techniques. Researchers supported by this grant (including PIs) will also be active in outreach to K-12 schools in the Santa Barbara area. Researchers working on this project also plan to develop a demonstration of an operating fuel cell that will be included in the currently active outreach program in the chemistry department here at UCSB. In addition, they will visit high schools in the Santa Barbara and Ventura Counties three times per year to discuss their research and its impact as well as to promote science education.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Over the past several years the Buratto research group has developed a suite of experimental methods that utilize tapping-mode atomic force microscopy (AFM) and conductive probe AFM (cAFM) to probe pore connectivity and ion transport in proton-conducting perfluorosulfonic acid (PFSA) membranes like Nafion, which are used in polymer electrolyte membrane fuel cells (PEMFCs).  Chemically, PFSA membranes consist of a fluorocarbon backbone with pendant perfluorosulfonic acid side chains, and when cast in films, phase separation between the hydrophobic and hydrophilic segments results in a random network of hydrophilic and hydrophobic domains and gives these membranes their desired properties of facile ion conductivity and mechanical strength.  The polymer electrolyte membrane is the quintessential nanomaterial with hydrophilic pores on the order of 10 nm through which ions are transported. Using the nanoscale resolution afforded by AFM, it was possible to probe the connectivity, map the spatial distribution, and measure the current carrying capacity of ion transport domains in polymer electrolytes over a range of conditions (temperature, relative humidity, and pH) in operating fuel cells on the relevant length scale.  In tapping-mode AFM experiments, differences in the probe-sample interaction time creates phase shifts between the drive and detected probe oscillation frequency, which was stronger for the hydrophilic domains than the hydrophobic regions.  Using AFM phase images it was possible to accurately map the nanoscale morphology of proton conducting domains and determine the size, number, and total area of the hydrophilic domains.  In addition, the Buratto group developed a method to directly probe the electrochemical activity of the hydrophilic surface domains using conductive probe AFM.  In this experiment one side of the Nafion membrane was hot pressed to a Pt containing carbon cloth gas diffusion electrode (0.5 mg/cm2 Pt), as in bulk fuel cell assembly.  Pt-coated AFM probes were simultaneously used for tapping-mode AFM phase imaging and nanoscale electrochemical current AFM (cAFM) imaging on the open side of the Nafion with the Pt coated probe acting as a nanoscale, moving cathode.  In this way it was possible to compare phase-contrast images to current images in order to elucidate the fraction of electrochemically active ion-rich surface domains.  In Nafion, it was found that on average ~58% of ion-rich surface domains in a given area were not electrochemically active, representing a potential source of loss in fuel cell performance. Using these AFM methods the Buratto group compared the surface morphology and aqueous phase connectivity of three different proton-conducting polymer materials, Nafion (a long chain PFSA polymer), Hyflon-Ion (a short chain PFSA polymer) and a perfluoro-imide acid (PFIA) polymer developed by 3M as a function of temperature and relative humidity.  Under dehydrated conditions, the size and number of aqueous domains shrink significantly for Nafion but remained relatively unchanged for Hyflon ion and for the PFIA membrane, indicating better water retention capability for the Hyflon Ion and PFIA materials.  At ambient conditions, all three membrane materials exhibited surface morphology that resembled the parallel-pore and bicontinuous network models. At hydrated conditions, a new surface morphology was discovered in Nafion.  Worm-like fibril features that contained water, but were insulating to ion-transport were observed at the Nafion surface.  These fibrils had high aspect ratio and were several microns long.  These fibril features were attributed to reverse micelle tubes that formed parallel to the surface, which were filled with water and encased by the fluoropolymer.  It is important to note that the size of the fibril features and the mean distance between them were consistent with the low spatial frequency peaks observed and previously unassigned in small angle x-ray diffraction studies of these membrane materials under hydrated conditions.  While the surface of Nafion changed dramatically as a function of relative humidity, both Hyflon Ion and PFIA membrane surfaces exhibited little if any transformation over the same range of relative humidity.  These results were consistent with the improved ion-transport properties observed for both Hyflon Ion and PFIA membranes at high water contents.  These results shed important new light on the structure/function of these membrane materials and helped explain the difference in the conductive properties between the three materials.

The possibility of producing power with high efficiency and with environmentally benign byproducts, makes fuel cells an important player in the field of alternative energy and sustainability, especially if the reactants are derived from renewable resources.  Students that have worked on this project have helped optimize industrial processes that produce polyelectrolyte membranes, and provide important insight into the discovery of new membrane materials.  In addition, these students have been trained in state-of-the-art scanned probe microscopy and nano-characterization techniques.  Finally, the Buratto research group has been active in outreach activities to elementary schools and high schools in the Santa Barbara, CA and Ventura, CA areas.

 


Last Modified: 12/05/2016
Modified by: Steven Buratto

Image
  • (Left) 250 x 250 ?m phase image (dark features represent ion-rich surface domains) and (Right) current image (red features represent active surface domains; z-scale: 5 pA) of an operating half fuel cell using Nafion as the electrolyte. Both images were acquired simultaneously.
    unpublished
    Public Domain
    Steven Buratto
    cAFM of Nafion
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Over the past several years the Buratto research group has developed a suite of experimental methods that utilize tapping-mode atomic force microscopy (AFM) and conductive probe AFM (cAFM) to probe pore connectivity and ion transport in proton-conducting perfluorosulfonic acid (PFSA) membranes like Nafion, which are used in polymer electrolyte membrane fuel cells (PEMFCs). Chemically, PFSA membranes consist of a fluorocarbon backbone with pendant perfluorosulfonic acid side chains, and when cast in films, phase separation between the hydrophobic and hydrophilic segments results in a random network of hydrophilic and hydrophobic domains and gives these membranes their desired properties of facile ion conductivity and mechanical strength. The polymer electrolyte membrane is the quintessential nanomaterial with hydrophilic pores on the order of 10 nm through which ions are transported. Using the nanoscale resolution afforded by AFM, it was possible to probe the connectivity, map the spatial distribution, and measure the current carrying capacity of ion transport domains in polymer electrolytes over a range of conditions (temperature, relative humidity, and pH) in operating fuel cells on the relevant length scale. In tapping-mode AFM experiments, differences in the probe-sample interaction time creates phase shifts between the drive and detected probe oscillation frequency, which was stronger for the hydrophilic domains than the hydrophobic regions. Using AFM phase images it was possible to accurately map the nanoscale morphology of proton conducting domains and determine the size, number, and total area of the hydrophilic domains. In addition, the Buratto group developed a method to directly probe the electrochemical activity of the hydrophilic surface domains using conductive probe AFM. In this experiment one side of the Nafion membrane was hot pressed to a Pt containing carbon cloth gas diffusion electrode (0.5 mg/cm2 Pt), as in bulk fuel cell assembly. Pt-coated AFM probes were simultaneously used for tapping-mode AFM phase imaging and nanoscale electrochemical current AFM (cAFM) imaging on the open side of the Nafion with the Pt coated probe acting as a nanoscale, moving cathode. In this way it was possible to compare phase-contrast images to current images in order to elucidate the fraction of electrochemically active ion-rich surface domains. In Nafion, it was found that on average ~58% of ion-rich surface domains in a given area were not electrochemically active, representing a potential source of loss in fuel cell performance. Using these AFM methods the Buratto group compared the surface morphology and aqueous phase connectivity of three different proton-conducting polymer materials, Nafion (a long chain PFSA polymer), Hyflon-Ion (a short chain PFSA polymer) and a perfluoro-imide acid (PFIA) polymer developed by 3M as a function of temperature and relative humidity. Under dehydrated conditions, the size and number of aqueous domains shrink significantly for Nafion but remained relatively unchanged for Hyflon ion and for the PFIA membrane, indicating better water retention capability for the Hyflon Ion and PFIA materials. At ambient conditions, all three membrane materials exhibited surface morphology that resembled the parallel-pore and bicontinuous network models. At hydrated conditions, a new surface morphology was discovered in Nafion. Worm-like fibril features that contained water, but were insulating to ion-transport were observed at the Nafion surface. These fibrils had high aspect ratio and were several microns long. These fibril features were attributed to reverse micelle tubes that formed parallel to the surface, which were filled with water and encased by the fluoropolymer. It is important to note that the size of the fibril features and the mean distance between them were consistent with the low spatial frequency peaks observed and previously unassigned in small angle x-ray diffraction studies of these membrane materials under hydrated conditions. While the surface of Nafion changed dramatically as a function of relative humidity, both Hyflon Ion and PFIA membrane surfaces exhibited little if any transformation over the same range of relative humidity. These results were consistent with the improved ion-transport properties observed for both Hyflon Ion and PFIA membranes at high water contents. These results shed important new light on the structure/function of these membrane materials and helped explain the difference in the conductive properties between the three materials. The possibility of producing power with high efficiency and with environmentally benign byproducts, makes fuel cells an important player in the field of alternative energy and sustainability, especially if the reactants are derived from renewable resources. Students that have worked on this project have helped optimize industrial processes that produce polyelectrolyte membranes, and provide important insight into the discovery of new membrane materials. In addition, these students have been trained in state-of-the-art scanned probe microscopy and nano-characterization techniques. Finally, the Buratto research group has been active in outreach activities to elementary schools and high schools in the Santa Barbara, CA and Ventura, CA areas.
